entry.content:
(source)

Creature - Human Soldier
First strike
Whenever Precinct Captain deals combat damage to a player, put a 1/1 white Soldier creature token onto the battlefield.

via MTG Salvation 

Oh yay, finally a human who's a person of color in RTR :'D

Oh wait

Wait, does she stand for the token?

As in...token black woman?

@__@

I want to make some joke about how it can't be because "white Soldier," but I'm too tired of zombie trolls, sphinxes, elf shamans, elephant soldiers, and whatever the heck a shred-freak is being easier to make up than a non-white human doing something other than existing namelessly in the background.

entry.title: [Microaggression] Tumblr Posts Where There's Some Girl Posing by a Nerd Thing and Other People Mock Her
entry.content:
I feel like I run into a lot of posts on Tumblr which have this formula:

  1. Find picture of a girl posing "attractively" near a nerd-related thing; ex. a girl placing her cheek next to a game controller or TCG item and staring into the camera
  2. Reblog, with a photo of yourself contorting your face next to a nerd-related thing

It's meant to be funny, but I think the underlying humor of this joke is related to these idea that girls shouldn't be showing themselves off to people. (Sluts!)

Part of the funny may relate to the assumption that this girl is using cards to appear "nerdy," which is nowadays "a new stereotype of femininity." You can't tell that this is the case from a single picture.  I mean, how could you rationalize it?  This girl doesn't really like Yu-Gi-Oh! cards!  She's just showing off!  Yeah!  Go sit back in your corner and where no one can see you, shoo!  Only then can you really be a True Nerd.

entry.title: [Microaggression] Morkrut Banshee
entry.content:
(source)


This creature's jaw is falling off and yet her boobs are smooth as a newborn.  It's an unnecessary (and hilariously disturbing) sexualization.  It's not even relevant to her flavor text, which is something bland about how those with resentments in life are evidently doomed to become (very well-endowed) unhallowed in their afterlife.

Contrast with Diregraf Ghoul, who appears to be a monstrous woman, but doesn't indulge the male gaze:

(source)

I don't want every monstrous character to be "ugly."  But cards featuring male-looking creatures have so much variety: Abattoir Ghoul, Grimgrin, Elder of Laurels, Disciple of Griselbrand.  In contrast, female-looking characters in the majority are pale-skinned, slender, and/or have large boobs.


Edit: AAAHHHH <3

entry.title: [Microaggression] Signing Up for StumbleUpon
entry.content:
Really, StumbleUpon?  You're going to ask for my gender so that you can find the best sites for me?

Oh, right, because, now that you know I identify as female, you can show me female websites.  Like, ones with makeup.  Or pink.

But...it's okay!  Because this is what's best for me.  As a female!

I understand that women do tend to be more into certain things -- eyeliner, FarmVille, Edward Cullen, good hair days.  Even I cannot fight against the allure of kittens and arupaka.

But the reason why women tend to be into these things is because we are told, These are the things that you should love, these are the things that are best for you as a woman.


I'm sure that websites have been partitioning people and withholding information inappropriate to their stereotype for a while, but I've never seen it admitted so blatantly.  Some time ago I found out that Google shows me the same ads that it would a man 25 to 24 years of age (though now it seems that it just shows me the categories it has me listed under, versus actually giving me a gendered/aged demographic that I fit), but there's something more insidious about changing the actual websites that I might see, based not on my browsing history, but merely on Are you a boy?  Or a girl?

Anyway, I've lived successfully without StumbleUpon thus far, I can probably stand to be without it for a little longer.

Nope, it really did start at age 24 when I last checked! Very strange. I tried to find that page again when writing this post and couldn't, can you tell me how you found it yourself?

Even if it is "the programming bit" (HAHA) that made us seem more "male" than we are, it still makes me wonder how they calculate a gender binary for certain topics, and what it would take to change it. With Google, it's probably not some all-knowing human christening these different, inanimate topics with specific genders :P
